content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Vraiment intéressant !

Like I said 2 years ago, this is a really tough problem...

Your solution is not something anyone could think of in 15 minutes, let alone 5.

Recursion is a big ask for 5-15 minutes too, and then like I mentioned before the huge final tests make the recursive solution fail anyway.

I just got this in Shortest mode and won with 60% by just finding my own pattern based on the test cases that seemed to be right most of the time, and then patching up some of the edge cases where it failed with some ternary statements.
https://www.codingame.com/clashofcode/clash/report/41346729fe3f38f6f0ea21699a73e576ecd4f56

My heuristic was "(W*H/2.0).ceil+H-1" but I had no real idea why it worked, I just figured it out using the "10000 10000 -> 50009999" test case and then honed it on the others...
Why does the diagram for the 1st example in the problem statement have 31 *'s, but the expected output is 30?

This problem is way too hard to solve without recursion in 5 minutes, but then the final challenge is too deep for recursion to solve.

Luckily, your harder challenges are both cases were w=h, so you can use the 10000,10000 case to figure out a heuristic that when w=h the length is (w*w/2.0+w-1).round, but it's a very inelegant solution to use recursion and then a hacky formula. Looking at your solution for general cases, it's really not obvious how anyone could work that out in 15 minutes, let alone 5.

I think this challenge would be better if the toughest test case was at most [w,h].max=8000 - as then recursive solutions are possible (at least in Ruby). Recursion is the smart way to solve this puzzle, but the extreme test case and validator make it fail.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Because it's chalenging. Although, am not sure i could personally solve it in less than 5 minutes.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good and cool !
I agree with Andriamanitra.  Do one with 10,000 x 10,000

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: this is a nice possibility for recursion.
"Not even a complete ring" Validator should be 9, and your example should be 31.

Goal section
* "lenght" should be spelled as "length".

Input section
* Suggest to rewrite as "2 integers [[W]] and [[H]] separated by a space, for the width and height of the spiral".

Output section
* Suggest to rewrite as "An integer [[L]] for the length of the spiral, or {{NULL}}".

Constraint section
* Input is 0 in some cases and that is not consistent with the constraints.

I think you missed the point. 
Please loot at the puzzle definition, I added this case as an example.
Maybe the instructions aren't clear enough. What did you understand, at first sight ?
